author: timbeiko
content: Phone about to die, but one constraint to Â«Â solving itÂ Â» is getting a good enough proxy for demand thatâ€™s **easy to calculate based on the previous blockâ€™s data, ideally only the header**

author: andi9314
content: I haven't seen an argument yet for how 1559 in the long term increases gas fees. There's actually a downward pressure because average block size tends to be larger than the target size.

author: andi9314
content: Why can't we use the current block's data, and have the miner pay the tax after their block is mined?

author: sky.cactus
content: Eh, Ethereum usage is incredibly volatile so comparing between days/months/years is largely pointless I think.

author: timbeiko
content: There is no Â«Â current blockÂ Â» we come to consensus on until it is added to the chain, an then becomes the Â«Â previous blockÂ Â». Miners can always modify their Â«Â pendingÂ Â» block costlessly

author: sky.cactus
content:
Block space is not a temporally transferable resource.  Block space becomes available at intervals, and those intervals don't necessarily align with demand volatility.  As long as those two things aren't in perfect alignment, you should expect to see high volatility in gas prices.

This is similar to how the cost of using a toll road is *way* cheaper in the middle of the night than at rush hour.  You can't move the night toll road to the day, all you can do is lower the cost at night to try to encourage more people to travel at night.

author: sky.cactus
content: In the case of Ethereum blocks, this happens every 15 seconds instead of every 24 hours is all.

author: andi9314
content: Okay, let me rephrase: the fee for a block can be determined after the block is mined, as a function of the block's data (which is can now be called the previous block).

author: timbeiko
content: Isnâ€™t that the current mechanism?

author: timbeiko
content: You canâ€™t change a miner block

author: andi9314
content: Right now the base fee for a block is known before the block is mined since it's determined by the previous blocks

author: timbeiko
content: *mined

author: andi9314
content: I'm saying we can look at a block's size after it has been mined, and then make the miner pay a fee as a function of the size

author: sky.cactus
content: <@806752647088439306> Creating blocks becomes *incredibly* difficult when you don't know what the base fee is before you start filling it with transactions.

author: sky.cactus
content: Without knowing the base fee in advance, you don't know which transactions are valid at the beginning, so you would have to craft a hypothetical block, then go and remove transactions that are invalid, re-execute the block, and repeat.  Also, as you drop transactions then transactions that came after those may change in size, so removing a transaction may not actually change the block size and you may need to repeat many times.

author: sky.cactus
content: When you add in out of band transactions (that are getting left out of the block intentionally due to out of band agreements), things only get even more complicated.

author: andi9314
content: All transactions are valid, it's just a matter of revenue optimization. And if miners are ordering by gas price now, they can do the same thing. They just stop when the marginal fee is higher than the gas price.

author: andi9314
content: Just as they would stop if they reached the block size limit.

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, you are proposing that block authors buy gas essentially, and then (presumably) resell it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I'm not totally against that scheme, but it is a major design change that requires a complete and thorough writeup of the exact mechanisms.

author: sky.cactus
content: I don't think I have seen a complete writeup anywhere, just people mentioning it as an idea here and there.

author: andi9314
content: That's a good way to put it.

author: andi9314
content: It's certainly a major change. I might try to write something up

author: pietjepuk
content: How do you make sure that the miner _can_ pay? (has enough)

author: andi9314
content: We can reduce their base reward. Basically make the base reward a decreasing function of block size.

author: pietjepuk
content: Yes, that's my point. You need to stay below 2 ETH in that case (or a fraction of that for PoS). But how can you enforce this?

author: andi9314
content: We would just set the fee so that it increases in block size and hits 2 ETH when the block size hits 100%

author: pietjepuk
content: I'm not sure if some part is always burnt already, but 2 ETH is definitely not a high enough cap

author: pietjepuk
content: demand has exceeded that for long periods of time in the past, and again, PoS will have much lower base reward

author: andi9314
content: Something like this, where g_max is block size limit and MT is the marginal tax (marginal fee)

author: andi9314
content: Once we have PoS, can't we just slash them

author: pietjepuk
content: No, different layers

author: andi9314
content: When you say 2 ETH is not enough, you mean it's not high enough as the fee for a 30M block?

author: pietjepuk
content: I haven't seen your fully worked out proposal, and I'm still not sure if there is a base_fee like thing that is always burnt right away

author: andi9314
content: Oh you meant in my proposal. No, I wasn't thinking of having that.

author: pietjepuk
content: So if pre-London the sum of the tx fees was like 3-4 ETH for hours on end (i.e. higher than the block reward), what would happen with your fee-mechanism?

author: andi9314
content: Blocks would be larger than the target (but not necessarily full) during those hours, and miners would be willing to pay the fee that comes with larger blocks because tx fees make up for it

author: andi9314
content: Not necessarily full because the marginal cost of adding a tx can be arbitrarily large even if the total fee is capped at 2 ETH

author: pietjepuk
content: but miners will pay at most 2 ETH for block space, where demand is willing to pay more than that

author: andi9314
content: We can say that the last 1 gas in the block costs 1 ETH

author: andi9314
content: And all the gas before that costs 1 ETH, pro rata

author: andi9314
content: That's an extreme example but you see what I'm saying

author: andi9314
content: That last gas will never be used

author: andi9314
content: In this graph, the area below the red curve is 2 ETH, but the red curve evaluated at g_max can be much higher than 2  ETH

author: pietjepuk
content: I'm not sure what problem that will solve tbh, if you don't have a base_fee like system. At first glance it will just make fees really hard to predict again for end-users

author: andi9314
content: I'm thinking fee prediction is always hard no matter what we do. Maybe it will be a bit easier under 1559 once things stabilize a bit. But this proposal is more about flexible allocation of block space and burning more ETH

author: pietjepuk
content: I tend to disagree to be honest. Fee prediction with EIP-1559 is a _lot_ better than it was before

author: andi9314
content: Maybe you're right. But I think block space allocation is more important than fee prediction. Fees themselves are not a loss for the system as a whole, they are just transfers from users to miners. It's better if they are predictable, but the fact that people in the same block pay different fees by itself doesn't imply there is inefficiency. On the other hand, block space allocation directly changes the overall efficiency of the protocol.

author: pietjepuk
content: I'm not sure what you mean with block space allocation. Is it that you want a constant rate of gas/sec?

author: andi9314
content: I mean we want to have large blocks when there is high demand and small blocks when demand is low

author: andi9314
content: in this spirit

author: pietjepuk
content: Ah, OK. There's definitely room for improvement there, I agree. But I personally wouldn't sacrifice the price-predictability aspects for it (or the security improvements EIP-1559 brings by further avoiding a fee-dominated chain).

author: andi9314
content:
It would be nice to have some empirical evidence on fee predictability after UIs get upgraded. 
I think there's a fundamental conflict between fee predictability and allocation efficiency, though. To efficiently allocate block space, you have to stop relatively low-value transactions from filling up a block. But to do that, you have to make them pay for filling up their block, which can't be done if we fix the fee for that block before it's mined.

author: andi9314
content: It's like trying to charge a toll based on congestion and at the same time have a fixed toll.
